answers.author: Jay Gsell
answers.text:
Mike - Key questions in anticipation - what about emergency and law enforcement personnel in a declared state of emergency being precluded from Striking or showing solidarity by engaging in "blue Flu"? State statutes that provide certain protections for municipal governments in times of labor unrest,community safety and sceurity usually trump labor disputes and other legal means- injunctions, court orders to preempt labor actions and then all the things outlined in the guide Pam M provided could be adapted to the public sector. interesting that you are in WI( I worked in EaU Claire last century)the current hotbed of union unrest and teacher corp feigning sick time to protest Gov Walker's stance on budgets and public sector employee benefits cost escalation.

answers.author: Steven Wilke
answers.text:
Labor unrest for all public employees is pretty high. Probably more a fear of the unknown. Without collective bargaining - coffee breaks, work hours, vacation and holidays are a council vote away from changing. The Police are really torn - union brothers or we got what we wanted. I appreciate the help - I understand all the major unions are calling for a general strike if the budget passes. I assume the Council wants me to be prepared to repsond.

answers.author: Paul Scher
answers.text:
The State of Wisconsin has a long history with labor relations--it was the first state in the Union to enact a state constitutional Workmen's Compensation Act. This year, the centennial anniversary of that legislation, has been characterized by state budgetary crises and the accompanying push for austerity measures. The current efforts by Governor Wilson and many legislators to limit public workers' collective bargaining rights has sparked labor union supporters to march on Madison.  The following is a link I found for dealing with public sector labor disputes:     http://www.spa.ucla.edu/calpolicy/files05/CPO-MTAp.pdf    I hope you find it useful.
